loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 43 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is widowed and has six children, four of whom are currently in school. For the past five years, Fatuma has been working hard to manage her business, in which she sells maize and produce. 

To help expand her business, Fatuma has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more bags of maize, and will help Fatuma to generate greater profits and transition into selling wholesale. Fatuma hopes that in the future she will be able to open other wholesale businesses. 

Fatuma is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small business entrepreneurs like Fatuma who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more bags of maize.

loans.name: Adriana María

texts.es:
Adriana vive en el municipio de San Felix donde inició  su negocio de venta de mercancía en un local arrendado, con este negocio ella se consigue su sustento diario para ella y su pequeño hijo de 6 años.

Ella se sueña con tener su local propio y con un almacén con variedad de mercancía para ofrecerle a sus clientes, además así le puede brindar a su hijo una estabilidad económica y emocional.
texts.en:
Adriana lives in the city of San Felix. She started her business, selling merchandise, in a rented space. With this business she is able to provide daily sustenance for herself and her small six-year-old son. 
Her dream is to own her own property and have a small grocery store there with a variety of merchandise to offer to her customers. She would also like to provide her son with economic and emotional stability.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Fredy Alberto

texts.es:
Durante algunos años Fredy se ha desempeñado como operario en algunas empresas de Medellín y desea iniciar su propio negocio para ofrecerle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia conformada por su esposa y sus dos hijos de 16 y 17 años.

En su propia casa desea adecuar un espacio para iniciar con una sala de internet para ofrecerle este servicio a sus vecinos y para ello necesita de un préstamo para realizar las adecuaciones locativas del espacio.
texts.en:
For some years, Fredy has worked for various companies in Medellín, but he now wants to start his own business so that he can offer a better quality of life to his family, which consists of his wife and two children, who are 16 and 17.

He wants to remodel part of his house to start an internet cafe so he can offer this service to his neighbors.  He will use this loan to make the necessary changes to the space.

loans.use: convert part of his home into an internet cafe.

loans.name: Angelica

texts.es:
Angelica forma parte del Banco comunal “Villa Unida”, perteneciente a la comuna de San Javier, ubicada en la ciudad de Talca.
Ella se dedica al rubro del comercio, específicamente atiende un almacén y botillería desde hace 14 años.
Su local está ubicado en un costado de su casa. Comenta que le va muy bien en su negocio, a pesar de la competencia en el sector donde vive.
Su horario de atención es de lunes a domingo de 10ºº de la mañana hasta las 02ºº de la madrugada. 
Su mercadería la compra a los proveedores que van directamente a su casa, también concurre a las distribuidoras. 
Con el crédito comprará materiales de construcción, para reparar el techo de su local, además comprará mercadería para abastecer su negocio.
Las metas en su negocio son mejorar la infraestructura de su local, para tener una mayor comodidad. 
Angelica vive junto a sus dos hijos y un nieto de 9 años de edad.  Sus hijos están terminando sus carreras universitarias, por lo que se siente muy orgullosa del logro obtenido con gran esfuerzo.
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad que le ha brindado Fondo esperanza, ya que le ha permitido invertir en su negocio. Además se siente muy cómoda con las reuniones y grupo del Banco comunal del cual forma parte, ya que es unido, comprometido y responsable. 
San Javier es una comuna y ciudad de la zona central de Chile, perteneciente a la región del Maule. Se caracteriza por ser una zona esencialmente vitivinícola. Los viñedos locales pertenecen a la zona denominada Valle del Loncomilla, de donde provienen algunos de los mejores vinos chilenos, Viña Carolina y Viña Gillmore, entre otras.
texts.en:
Angelica is a member of the 'Villa Unida' community bank which is located in San Javier, in the city of Talca.  She is a shopkeeper and has run a grocery store and off licence for 14 years.  Angelica's premises are located on one side of her house.  She says that her business is doing very well, despite the competition in her area.

Angelica's opening hours are from Monday to Sunday, from 10.00am to 02.00am.  She buys her merchandise from suppliers who come directly to her home.  She also visits wholesalers.  She will use her loan to buy building materials to fix the roof of her premises.  She will also buy merchandise with which to stock her business.  Her business goals are to improve the infrastructure of her premises so that she can be more comfortable.

Angelica lives together with her two children and a 9-year-old grandson.  Her children are finishing their university degree courses and she feels very proud of what they have managed to achieve as a result of her hard work.

Angelica is very happy and grateful for the opportunity that Fondo Esperanza have given her as it has allowed her to invest in her business.  She also feels very comfortable with the meetings of her community bank as it is a very united, committed and responsible group.

San Javier is a district and city in the central area of Chile, in Maule region.  It is noted for being essentially a wine-growing area.  The local vineyards are in an area called 'Valle del Loncomilla' where some of the best Chilean wines come from (Viña Carolina, Viña Gillmore and others).

loans.use: to buy building materials to repair the roof of her premises and to buy merchandise with which to stock her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy Omela milk, toothpaste, biscuits, batteries, scented soap and sardines for his business.

loans.name: Gerrybeth

texts.en: Gerrybeth is married and works hard to support her family. She has operated a fishing business in the Philippines for 10 years. She earns additional income from food sales. Gerrybeth has requested a PHP 23,000 loan through NWTF to buy fishing gear and other equipment for fishing. In the future, Gerrybeth would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and equipment

loans.name: Drissa

texts.fr:
Né en Janvier 1983 à Sikasso, Monsieur Drissa est marié et réside chez son frère à Kaboïla II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Drissa n’ayant pas eu la chance de progresser dans les études, s’est vite initié à cette activité d’achat et de vente de téléphones portables et leurs accessoires (façade, batterie, chargeur, écouteur, etc.) il y a environ trois ans. Son activité est menée dans sa propre boutique au grand marché de Sikasso avec une clientèle composée de toutes les couches sociales et surtout des forains. Il est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ une année. Il a bénéficié deux crédits qui ont été correctement remboursés. Dans le but de mieux relancer cette activité, il sollicite ainsi un troisième crédit qui lui permettra d’acheter à Bamako 20 téléphones portables de marques différentes, 3 cartons de façade, 20 chargeurs, 20 paquets de carte mémoire, 5 cartons de batterie et 2 douzaines d’écouteur. 
 Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born in January 1983 in Sikasso, Drissa is married and lives with his brother in Kaboïla II, one of the neighborhoods of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).
Since he did not get a chance to further his education, Drissa quickly got into the business of buying and selling cell phones and phone accessories (covers, batteries, chargers, headphones, etc.) 3 years ago. He does this at his own booth in the big market of Sikassa, with a client base composed of all social classes, but especially itinerant merchants. Because of their quality, the products he sells are in high demand.
In order to better meet the needs of his growing clientele, he decided to partner with Soro Yiriwaso, a microfinance institution, about a year ago. He was granted 2 loans, which have been successfully paid back. In order to boost his business, he is applying for a third loan which will enable him to buy 20 phones of various brands, 3 boxes of phone covers, 20 packs of memory cards, 5 boxes of batteries, and 2 dozens of headphones in Bamako.
He expects to make a monthly profit of 200.000 FCFA, which will be mostly used to contribute to his family's expenses, pay back his loan, and reinvest in his business.

loans.use: to buy cell phones and phone accessories

loans.name: Wycliffe

texts.en:
Wycliffe is 39 years old and married with two children aged 9 and 16. He bakes to earn a living. He has been in the business for three years and has employed three people. 

He describes his business environment as favorable because there is limited competition. Since he joined Faulu Kenya he has been able to expand his business. He hopes to be financially stable in the future. He has applied for 50,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to buy baking powder and cooking oil.

loans.use: To buy baking powder and cooking oil

loans.name: Osman

texts.en:
This is 44 year-old Osman.  He is married and has 4 children who are 14, 11, and 9 (female twins). He has 2 additional dependents, who attend school and  assist with the domestic work. 

Osman owns a business to sell used clothes, shoes, suitcases, refrigerators, bed spreads, carpets, slippers, handbags, and televisions.  He began his business because he  could not have a better education and needed to stop at the primary level.  He used to help his father with his faming business.  He saved the commissions that were given to him by his father. Later, he started  traveling to Guinea Conakry to buy jewelry and men and women's clothes.  He was doing it on a credit basis and later transformed his business to include used items.  

He works 7 days a week, 10 hours a day and earns 2,200,000 SLL every month.  He would like to borrow 5,000,000 SLL to purchase the following items: large quantities of used clothes, trousers, bed spreads, shoes, carpets, and  handbags. He is friendly and accommodating.  The major challenge is not having a shop.  

In the future, Osman plans to rent a shop, educate his children to higher levels, and to build a house.  The loan will help him to earn more profit as it is an additional income. 

 He thanks you for your support  and promises to repay within the stipulated dates and continue the program.

loans.use: to buy more goods.

loans.name: Sagrario Norela

texts.en:
For the last years, I’ve been a peddler who sells beauty products. I visit offices, neighbors and markets in order to sell lotions and clothes. I work from Monday to Saturday, and my sales have gone up in the last few months. During the Christmas season, people buy gifts and accessories for personal use, and that helps me with my sales. I’m a single mother, so I have to look for ways to help my kid financially. This is a good month for sales, so I need to invest money in order to increase my inventory, and my income.

Loan Use: Purchase lotions, shampoo, everyday lotions, etc.

Desde hace dos años me dedico a la venta de productos de belleza ambulante, visito oficinas, vecinas y mercados para vender cremas, lociones y ropa. Trabajo de lunes a sabado y mis ventas han incrementado en estos ultimos meses. Ahora en temporada navideña las personas buscan comprar regalos o accesorios de uso personal lo que me ayuda a mi producto se venda. Soy madre soltera por lo que tengo que buscar la manera de ayudar economicamente a mi hijo. Este mes es bueno para ventas por lo que necesito invertir capital para incrementar mi inventario y obtener mejores ingresos.

loans.use: Compra de lociones, Shampoo, Cremas de uso diario y otros.

loans.name: Benito

texts.en:
Benito is a rice farmer in Santa Lucia. He is the leader of the cooperative of rice farmers and field workers named Dios Con Nosotros (God is with Us). His job as leader is to make sure that his fellow borrowers are on time and no one falls behind. He needs this loan in order to purchase all the necessary items to plant rice on his lands. He has been a rice farmer for over 20 years, and he is sure that the access to capital will help him and his fellow cooperative members be more productive than ever. He hopes that this is the first step in bypassing loan sharks and intermediaries who take many of the profits that he and his fellow field workers would otherwise make.

The Paypayales Communal Bank in Santa Lucia

Benito is part of one of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program: the Paypayales Communal Bank. All bank members are part of a rice farmers' cooperative in Santa Lucia named Dios Con Nosotros (God is with us). They will use these microloans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. As members of a communal bank, they are all the guarantors for each other's loans. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Dios con Nosotros Cooperative are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many microfinance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we works with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about the commnity of Santa Lucia, compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The region is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area, as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with the rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them harvest their crop. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not have access to formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also often lack skills and knowledge of how to commercialize their product and get fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is different from the typical microentrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them to repay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Farm Rice

loans.name: Shahin

texts.en: Shahin N. is a native of the Aghsu region of Azerbaijan. He is married with four children. He started his trade business in 1990 selling small items from a table in front of his house. Over the years his business has grown and with the help of a loan of $500 from Normicro he was able to obtain a small store to sell his goods. Shahin is now requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a wider variety of goods and products to satisfy the needs of his growing customer base.

loans.use: To purchase more goods and products to stock his general store

loans.name: Karla Elizabeth

texts.es:
Karla is single and has four children, who are studying. She has never had anyone's assistance in helping her children get ahead, so for 10 years, she has been working with the sales of used clothing, and then she began making and selling pasteles (savory pastries). this has been her only income to support and educate her children, and it has not been easy for her to have the entire responsibility for her family. But her love for her children is what drives her forward from day to day.

Thanks to the good quality of the pasteles she makes, she has grown her business and is now requesting a loan of $250 that will be used to purchase goods to increase her production and meet her clients' demand. She promises to return this amount in 3 months. The well-being of this family is in your hands. Help them by contributing to the growth of her business, and they will sincerely thank you.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Karla es soltera y tiene cuatro hijos, que se están estudiando. Nunca ha tenido la ayuda de nadie para sacar adelante a sus hijos, por lo que desde hace 10 años se dedica a la venta de ropa usada, después inició con la elaboración y venta de pasteles, este ha sido su único ingreso para sostener y dar educación a sus hijos, no ha sido fácil para ella tener toda la responsabilidad de su familia, pero el amor hacia sus hijos es lo que la impulsa día a día.

Gracias a la buena calidad de pasteles que elabora ha hecho crecer su negocio y ahora está solicitando un préstamo de $ 250 dólares que empleará en la compra de insumos para incrementar su producción y cubrir la demanda de sus clientes, ella promete regresar esta cantidad en 3 meses. En tus manos está el bienestar de esta familia, ayúdalos contribuyendo al crecimiento de su negocio, ellos te lo agradecen sinceramente.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Gogosina

texts.en: Gogosina is 37 years of age and married with 5 children. Her parents run a small retail shop in the village. About a year ago, Gogosina's father passed away, and left her with her mother and two grown-up sisters. She's looking after the shop, which is why she decided to join SPBD. With the help of SPBD she managed to expand her shop, and she managed to sell enough goods. Some of the women in the village are using Gogo's shop, as she is known, to display their goods, for example, cabbage, beans, coconuts, etc.

loans.use: To assist with the family's shop

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
Pedro Coronoal is a 35-year-old physical education teacher and nutritionist. He is single and lives with his mother and four brothers. He and his brothers work hard to ensure their independence from their mother. 
After finishing his studies to become a physical education teacher and nutritionist, Pedro has begun his work in this field. He has been able to achieve this level of success with the ongoing support of his family. He has been working in this field for the last seven years. His business is growing and he has established a number of regular clients. 
Pedro has asked for a small loan to allow him to buy new weights for his gym, which will open early this summer as people try to get in shape for the warm weather. The loan will allow him to continue successfully in this line of work.

loans.use: TO INVEST IN NEW WEIGHTS FOR HIS GYM, AND HELP GROW HIS BUSINESS AS A PHYSICAL EDUCATION TEACHER AND NUTRITIONIST

loans.name: Vicenta

texts.es:
Vicenta lives in her own home with her three children on Mario Alborta street in the Tembladerani district of the city of La Paz. She sells food, perfume and electronics in schools and in her neighborhood. She delivers her goods on credit and collects money on a daily basis. She will use this loan to increase her capital so that she can offer a wider variety of products.

She does not have a loan history with Impro but the socioeconomic analysis conducted qualifies her to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

La señora Vicenta vive en casa propia con sus tres hijos en la calle Mario Alborta de la zona de Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz. Su actividad es la venta de víveres, perfumes, artefactos eléctricos, ya sea en los colegios y por su zona entregándolos al crédito y cobrando diariamente , el crédito que solicita es para aumentar su capital y así tener más variedad de productos para ofrecer.

No tiene antecedente histórico con Impro pero por la evaluación socio económica efectuada ella califica para obtener un préstamo.

loans.use: Increase capital to purchase more merchandise.

loans.name: Rose Kizito's Group

texts.en: Rose is 35 years old and married with five children. She has a market stall where she sells foodstuffs. Rose wants to use the extra profits from her business to buy iron sheets for her stall and to complete her the floor of her house.

loans.use: Increase her business profits.

loans.name: Muborak

texts.en:
A. Muborak is 54 years old. She and her husband have raised three children, the elder is already married. 

For 11 years Muborak has been running her own business. She is selling  socks in the central local market. As a rule she receives the goods from the  neighboring city of Istaravshan. Considering that the husband of Muborak is currently unemployed, her business is the main source of income for the family. Muborak is working hard and hoping to educate her younger children and to improve the living conditions of the family.

Today Muborak requests 200.00 US Dollars for the term of 3 months. She is planning to enlarge the range of goods for selling. Muborak promises to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing of goods like socks for men and women in order to enlarge the range of goods

loans.name: Johari's Nyota Group

texts.en:
Johari is 38 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, aged 14, 9, and 3. Johari owns a small stationery store, which she started in 2006. Every day she works from 9:00 AM to 6:30 PM at her business.

Johari now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing in food vending and charcoal selling.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business

loans.name: Yim

texts.en:
Mr. Yim Y. is 62 years old and lives in the Kroal Krabei Village, Pursat Province. He farms and raises pigs, earning about $2.50 per day. His wife, Mrs. Sen In, is 55 years old. Sen sells porridge and Khmer noodles from her home and earns about $2.30 per day. Y. has seven children, two of whom are married.

Mr. Y. requests a loan of $500 to purchase small pigs to raise. Y. hopes this loan will increase his income and sustain his family’s financial stability. Sen In is pictured in the photo because Yim Y. was not available at the time.

loans.use: To purchase small pigs to raise

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret M. is thirty years old. She is married with a child. She has been a retailer of charcoal for five years. Margaret is very grateful for the previous loan which made a big difference in her business and family's life. She wants to use the next loan to buy more charcoal stock to serve her customers. She also wants to expand the business to include food stuffs like maize and plantain which are mostly requested by customers. She believes this can help to increase her income to provide a decent shelter for her family. She belongs to the community group called Nyame Asomafo (God’s Ambassadors). Members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of charcoal.

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Dewi

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman Dewi believes that working hard is important, and she has done so for many years. To ensure the longterm survival of her family and to help relieve some of the burden of her hard work, she hopes to get another loan to help increase her family's income. Although already older in her years, as the wife of I Made Ardana, she must continue to farm pigs with as much energy as if she were newly married. Little by little her savings grows thanks to the pigs she is able to sell. She and her husband also save the money that her husband earns as a farm laborer on someone else's land. Their system of saving has already helped them to purchase their own piece of land. During her first loan from Kiva/Dinari Ni Nyoman Dewi received 1,400,000 Rupiah which she used to purchase 3 piglets. She was able to sell them for 3,500,000 Rupiah, netting her a profit of 1,200,000 Rupiah over 6 months, or 200,000 Rupiah/month. For her next loan Ni Nyoman Dewi plans to further increase her pig population so her profits further increase.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Courtenay Teska Race, Kiva Volunteer.

Untuk dapat mempertahankan kelangsungan hidup suatu keluarga dan bisa terlepas dari himpitan kebutuhan yang semakin banyak di butuhkan pengorbanan dan kerja keras. Karena dengan usaha dan bekerja keras pasti akan mendapatkan hasil yang lebih baik. Demikian prinsip yang di anut oleh Ni Nyoman Dewi. Meski tergolong sudah usia lanjut, Istri dari I Made Ardana ini masih memiliki semangat dalam menjalankan usaha ternak babi yang telah di tekuninya sejak baru menikah. Sedikit demi sedikit keuntungan yang di peroleh Ni Nyoman Dewi dari menjual babi ditabung. Dan bersama penghasilan suaminya yang berkerja sebagai petani ( mengerjakan sawah milik orang lain ). Dengan sistem bagi hasil keluarga ini telah mampu membeli sepetak tanah . Dalam pinjaman periode pertama, Ni Nyoman Dewi mendapat pinjaman modal Rp 1.400.000,-yang oleh Nyoman Dewi di belikan 3 ekor bibit babi. Babi itu kini telah laku dijual dengan harga Rp 3.500.000.- dengan keuntungan bersih yang di dapat Ni Nyoman Dewi sebesar Rp. 1.200.000.- 6 Bln atau Rp. 200.000.- bln. Dalam pinjaman tahap kedua ini, Ni Nyoman Dewi merencanakan untuk meningkatkan populasi ternaknya sehingga hasil yang didapatnya pun akan meningkat.

loans.use: to purchase piglets

loans.name: Sallay

texts.en:
This is Sallay C.; she sells palm oil here in Makeni town. Sallay, a widow with 2 children, is 55. For the past 25 years now, Sallay has been able to make ends meet through the selling of palm oil. Since she joined SMT, Sallay has experienced a great improvement in her life. Her stock of palm oil increases and ultimately, she realises greater profit than she used to before joining SMT.

Sallay has finished repayment successfully and without any hiccups. She is asking now for another loan of US$ 300.

loans.use: Buy more gallons of palm oil to increase the size of her business

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao P. is a grocer in the local market in Svay Chuor village in the Kandal province. Since her business is going well, Mrs. Mao P. would like to expand. She has asked for a loan in order to buy more grocery products to sell to her customers.

Mrs. Mao P. is 43 years old and the mother of five children, four of whom are employed in different jobs. The youngest child is attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Ny Rann, grows vegetables in the local village. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Kate

texts.en: Kate O. operates a restaurant and serves a variety of Ghanaian local dishes such as Fufu (made out of cassava), Omo-tuo (made out of rice), and other kinds of food at Yammoransah on the Cape Coast. Kate has received a junior high education, is married and has 5 children. Her husband is an administrator. Kate has been operating this restaurant since 2003. She is responsible for the children's school fees, food, and clothing, as well as the utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more rice, cassava, fish, and other ingredients she needs to prepare the food for her restaurant. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to provide a quality education for the children.

loans.use: To buy more rice, cassava, fish, and other ingredients

loans.name: Gina

texts.es: Gina tiene 31 años, es madre 3 hijos que están estudiando, ella trabaja arduamente para dar a sus hijos lo que necesitan, a pesar de ser madre soltera lucha mucho por ver a sus hijos felices y tranquilos.Se dedica a la venta de bebidas heladas (gaseosas, néctar y cerveza), es una mujer prometedora, cuando dice algo lo cumple y eso es superarse en su negocio. Gina, por las noches, también vende comida al paso.  Ahora quiere implementar su negocio con más productos de otras marcas, así como también ampliar y mejorar los ambientes de su tienda, para lograr este propósito requiere de dinero, por lo que solicita este préstamo, con el fin de cumplir su objetivo.
texts.en:
Gina is 31 years old and the mother of three children, all of whom are in school. She works very hard in order to provide her children with everything they need. Despite the hardships of being a single mother, she works hard to ensure that her children are happy and calm. She sells cold drinks (soda, juice and beer); she is a very promising woman who has pledged to get ahead with her business, and she always keeps her word. She also sells food at night. Now, she wants to stock her business with a wider variety of products of different brands and expand and improve the space of her store. In order to achieve this goal, she needs more money, which is why she has requested this loan from PRISMA.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expand store, buy a wider variety of merchandise to sell

loans.name: Eteldita

texts.es:
La señora Eteldita pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Doncellas”, ubicado en la calle 15 Mz. 26 Lt. 23 AA.HH Primavera Segunda Etapa, distrito de Callería, provincia de Coronel Portillo, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 33 años de edad,  es madre de 3 hijos menores de edad que aún dependen de ella, es casada y su esposo trabaja como independiente. Con el primer préstamo que recibió de  Manuela Ramos de S/. 300, decide invertir en la venta de productos de belleza. Tiene 4 años trabajando con Manuela Ramos. 

En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio y también se dedica a la venta de materiales de construcción (arena, ripio, piedras). 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,200, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 18 metros de arena, 5 metros de piedra, ripio y productos de belleza. 

Eteldita manifiesta que recibe un gran apoyo de Manuela Ramos porque su negocio ha crecido y desea seguir surgiendo en la vida.
texts.en:
Mrs. Eteldita belongs to the Communal Bank “Las Doncellas,” located at calle 15 Mz. 26 Lt. 23 AA.HH Primavera Segunda Etapa, Callería district, Coronel Portillo province, Ucayali department. She is 33 years old, mother of 3 small children who are still dependent on her, married, and her husband is an independent worker. With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S/.300, she decided to invest in beauty products. She has been working with Manuela Ramos for 4 years. Today she continues with the same business and also sells construction materials (sand, brick fragments, stone). With this loan for S/.1,200, which will be repaid in 5 months, she will buy 18 meters of sand, 5 meters of stone, brick fragments, and beauty products. Eteldita states that she receives great support from Manuela Ramos because her business has grown and she wishes to continue succeeding in life.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sand, stone, brick fragments, and beauty products

loans.name: Orlando Jose

texts.es: El señor Orlando José M.  Z. tiene la edad de 68 años habita en el sector de la borgoña ubicado en el municipio de Ticuantepe, junto a su esposa y hijos, los cuatro hijos de don Orlando le apoyan con el cultivos ya que se encargan de limpiar, sembrar y cuidar las tierras; cada unos de ellos trabaja por cuenta propia. La esposa de don M. trabaja como comerciante para ayudarle con los gastos de casa. El desde hace 40 años trabaja con sus cultivos. Don Orlando se siente muy contento ya que ha tenido el apoyo de Afodenic, y ha logrado salir adelante poco a poco con la producción. El solicita la cantidad de C$ 10.000.00 córdobas para comprar insumos y siempre mantener sus cultivos cuidados para sacarle mejor provecho.
texts.en:
Orlando José M. Z. is 68 years old and lives in the Borgoña sector located in the municipality of Ticuantepe, together with his wife and children. Orlando's four children help him with the crops, cleaning, planting and taking care of the land and all also work on their own. Orlando's wife works as a merchant to help him with the household expenses. He has been working with his crops for 40 years. Orlando is very content that he has had the support of Afodenic, and has managed to get ahead little by little with his production. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 Córdobas to purchase materials and maintain his crops to provide him with a better harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of incesticide and fertilizer to care for his crops

loans.name: Jessica

texts.es: Jessica tiene 34 años, vive con su madre y sus 2 hijos. Desde hace más de 3 años vende cosméticos por catálogo y su principal punto de venta es su centro de trabajo, ya que ella es docente y ha visto que la mejor forma de ofrecer sus productos es a sus amistades y personas conocidas, es así que aumentó durante este tiempo su mercadería y tiene proyectos de seguir creciendo, ya que  sus 2 hijos necesitan cada día más gastos para sus estudios. Los productos que Jessica vende son de las principales líneas de belleza, lo que garantiza sus ventas por ser productos de calidad. Es la primera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP, por lo que promete ser una clienta  responsable en sus pagos. En esta oportunidad invertirá en la compra de más productos, y así tener mayor cantidad de mercadería en stock, a la mano, para poder vender inmediatamente sin el catálogo.
texts.en:
Jessica is 34 years old, she lives with her mother and her 2 children. For more than 3 years she has been selling cosmetics from catalogue and her main point of sale is her working place as she is a teacher and has seen that the best way of offering her products is to friends and known individuals. During this time she has increased her merchandise and plans to keep growing as her 2 children need more financial support for their studies. The products Jessica sells are well-known quality brands and therefore her sales are good. This is the first time she requests a loan from MFP but she promises to be responsible with the repayments. The loan will be invested in buying more products to increase the stock and be able to sell inmediately without the catalogue.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase stock to improve business.

loans.name: Dang Thi

texts.vi: Chị Đặng Thị Luyến, 29 tuổi ở Thanh Hóa. Gia đình chị có  1 con còn nhỏ, hi ện t ịa ch ị Luyến đi chợ  buôn bán gà còn chồng chị làm nghề cơ khí, thu nhập cũng khá ổn định. Chị tham gia Qũy từ năm 2007, với số vốn vay được anh chị đã mở rộng thêm xưởng cơ khí, đ ầu tư kinh doanh, buôn bán đời sống được nâng cao với thu nhập 3.500.000 đ/ th áng.. Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn vay 9000.000 để đầu tư buôn bán ngan, gà và giúp chồng mở rộng thêm quy mô của xưởng cơ khí.
texts.en:
Mrs Dang Thi L., 29 years of age, lives in Thanh Hoa province. Her family has one young child. Currently Mrs. L. buys and sells chickens in the market. Her husband is a mechanic with a fairly stable income. She joined the Fund in 2007. With the loans, she and her husband expanded the mechanical workshop and increased the working capital for chicken trading, therefore the condition of living has improved, with an income of VND3,500,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND9,000,000 to invest further in duck and chicken trade, and help her husband to expand the mechanical workshop.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in duck and chicken trade, expand mechanical workshop

loans.name: Lazim

texts.en:
Lazim A. is a 39-year-old, married man with two children. Lazim sells confectioneries such as candies, cookies, pastries, and foodstuffs as sugar, salt, mayonnaise, and other items. He is proud that he has been in this line of business for approximately 8 years.

Lazim purchases his goods from the neighboring city. The income he is able to generate from his business allows him to support his family; he is the sole breadwinner in his family. Now, Lazim is requesting a loan in the amount of 1200 USD over a 14-month term, the proceeds of which will be used to expand his inventory of goods (i.e., he plans to purchase more foodstuffs). Lazim thanks everyone for their support, and he promises to repay his loan on time.

loans.use: purchase more foodstuffs for his little store

loans.name: Semilla Group

texts.es:
La asociación “Semilla” pertenece al centro focal Los Andes, ubicado en la zona  de Villa Tunara de la ciudad de El Alto,  trabaja junto a Pro-Mujer hace ocho años, aproximadamente.
Casadas en su mayoría tienen un promedio de cinco hijos cada una, en algunos casos sus parejas las abandonaron teniendo que hacerse cargo ellas solas de sus familias, es por ello que tuvieron la  necesidad de buscar actividades propias que les permita generar recursos para el bien de sus familias.
La asociación “Semilla” tiene diversas actividades, venden; ropa, queso, verduras, fruta, zapatos, otras venden chompas y mantillas tejidas a mano. Todas las socias  quieren mejorar sus negocios, para esto solicitan mayor capital para comprar mercadería y materia prima, dependiendo el caso. Están seguras que sus ventas aumentaran y podrán obtener ingresos suficientes para solventar  sus familias.
texts.en:
The Semilla Association belongs to the main center of Los Andes, located in the Villa Tunara zone of the city of El Alto. They have worked alongside Pro-Mujer for the past eight years, approximately. The majority of these women are married and they have an average of five children apiece. In some cases their partners abandoned them and they have had to work alone to care for their families. For this reason they needed to look for their own activities that would allow them to generate resources for the good of their families. The Semilla Association has diverse activities. They sell clothing, cheese, vegetables, fruit, and shoes. Others sell sweaters and hand-woven mantillas (veils). All the members want to improve their businesses so they are asking for a loan to buy merchandise and raw materials, depending on their business. They are sure their sales will increase and they will earn enough to solve their families' problems.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Urunbi

texts.en:
Urunbi is widowed and has one child. She has a business selling clothing in the small market of Shahrituz. Urunbi’s business is going well as demand has been very stable over the last 4 years. Urunbi is an entrepreneur of high integrity. She is very hard working and energetic. Even when her competitors have similar product or lower prices, clients naturally gravitate to her as she can skillfully make them feel valued and respected . Urunbi is requesting a loan of 2500 Somoni to purchase seasonal clothing which will help her to continue stabilizing her business and income so she can support herself and her daughter.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase new clothing for women for the spring season.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase cows for raising

loans.name: Crisilda

texts.en:
Crisilda O. is 33 years old and married to Romiel O.. They are blessed with two children and live in the town of Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. Her husband is a driver and receives an average monthly income of Php 9,000.

Crisilda’s business was already in existance before she become a member of Paglaum Coop. She is now one year into her membership. She loaned Php 15,000 for additional capital for her food-vending business . Her customers are her neighbors, friends and relatives. She is a good and hardworking mother. Paglaum help her business grow and to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy stocks of pork, vegetables, fruit and spices for her business

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
N. Nguyễn Thị is a 54-year-old woman living in the town of Quảng Xuong. She is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, N. raises pigs for sale. N. has just started operating this business and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month.

In 2006, N. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to improve her situation and enable her to engage in business activities. N. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000,000 VND from TYM Fund. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. N. is now requesting a loan of 9,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase new livestock to raise and sell. This will be her fourth loan from TYM Fund. N. plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business. No. 1701060004.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: The purchase of an electric oven and merchandise such as sodas, beers, etc.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris sells foodstuffs, cooking oil and drinks. She has been in business for the past 10 years to assist her husband with their children's upbringing. Doris has been borrowing from LAPO, a Kiva partner, for the past three years and is a faithful client. 

She goes to Cotonu once every two weeks to get goods in large quantities at a discount. She needs a loan of N160,000 to purchase more foodstuffs, which will enable her to meet customer demand. She says thank you and promises to pay back promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Funke

texts.en:
Funke is a tailor and she also sells tailoring materials. She hopes for the loan of N140,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell.

Funke is 29 years old and single without a child. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Badarch

texts.en:
Badarch C. is a 66-year-old widowed mother. Together with her grandson, Lhasuren, age 18, she lives in a ger (nomadic tent housing) district in Arhangai, one of Mongolia's central provinces. In 1999, her eldest daughter, who has three children, was widowed. Since then, Badarch decided to help her daughter by starting to run a small business selling household items such as soap and glue. Basically, she sells whatever can be sold.

When Badarch started her retail business, her working capital was 60,000 tugrugs (that is ~ $40 US). As a result of her hard work, the working capital has increased 1,900,000 tugrugs. With the profit, she has been paying her grandchildren's tuition. She requests a loan to purchase small household items from Ereen, a Chinese border city.

loans.use: To purchase small household items to resell

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en:
Hannah is fifty years old. She is married and the mother of six children. All of her children are in school, from polytechnic to the junior high school level. She works hand in hand with her husband to save enough for the future of her children. She enjoys selling and she is motivated to work hard because she dreams of a better future for her children. 

Hannah owns and operates a grocery shop and sells items like rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, bar soap etc. However, a lack of capital prevents her from making meaningful progress. She is requesting a loan to buy more rice, sugar, vegetable oil, body and hair creams etc. to make increased profits. She believes with her good customer relations, the loan will enable her to achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Rice Farm Group

texts.en:
Rice Farm is a group of five borrowers, led by Krubo K., who live in Zorzor, Lofa County, Liberia.  Krubo is 40 years old with five children ranging in age from 8 to 15. Her 15-year-old is in the 3rd grade because education was not available during the war, which was centered in Lofa County.

Krubo is a warm, friendly, natural mother who took care of many orphans during the war. She is illiterate because until recently school was not available to girls because women were expected to marry men who would provide the income.  Her brother and sister in-law died in 1993 during the civil war so Krubo also provides for their child. Krubo’s husband is a farmer but doesn’t earn enough to support the family. She lives in nearby Bokeza Town in a refugee camp because the town was burned to the ground during the war.

Krubo’s business is dry goods, such as food, housewares and clothing, which she imports from nearby Guinea. She sells in a temporary market stall alongside approximately 100 other vendors. She is successful because her customers like her personality and customer service. Her dream is to grow her business until she can build a permanent shop.  With the profits from her business Krubo dreams of building a permanent house to raise her family and send all her children to school.

loans.use: Purchase Inventory

loans.name: Artemio

texts.en:
“Never give up,” says Artemio of Barangay Labni, Mabuslo, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is a responsible father of four children and a loving wife to Victoria. He and his wife are helping one another to earn a living for their family and educate their children.

Artemio works as a motorcycle driver in his village, while his wife is managing a general store at home. Their income is budgeted to meet their daily needs with school allowances for their children.

Improving their small businesses requires financial capital. Artemio would like to borrow 5,000 PHP for motorcycle maintenance and for improvement of the store. He believes that he can improve their standard of living with financial assistance.

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Sahil

texts.en: Sahil was born in 1987. He lives in Fuzuli region. This young man is single. 4 years ago he started sheep breeding business. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy 16 sheep for improving his sheep breeding business.

loans.use: to buy 16 sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: more goods to add to the shop

loans.name: Kenneth's Group

texts.en: N. Kenneth is the leader of his lending group in Mukono. He is a friendly and very hard working man. He is married with three children, the eldest being 8 years old. Kenneth has owned and run a retail shop in Namayuba for four years. He is able to make 48000/= in profits per week. He ensures that he has good and necessary stock for his customers, enabling him to save. In the future, he would like to buy a plot of land as well as to continuously pay his children’s school fees on time. Kenneth needs a loan to be able to restock his retail business for expansion.

loans.use: To restock his retail business with more goods.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This borrower is a 60-year-old widow who is bringing up her nephew and taking care of him because his father passed away. She receives a pension for the loss of her family member.

She depends on sewing and tailoring clothes for the neighbors. This income is used to earn her living and support the child as well.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and fabric

loans.name: Agali Awamu Niwamanya Amina Group

texts.en: N. Amina is representing her group. She is a hardworking business lady living with her spouse. She has a dry cleaning shop where she carries out laundry services. She has been in this business for over two years. She is using the loan to widen her business by purchasing more flat irons, ironing tables, etc. She is very much encouraged due to the loan. Her dream is to work very hard and get the money to construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase more flat irons, ironing tables, etc.

loans.name: Help Us Group

texts.en:
Siah Wollie is a leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Help us. She is 31 years old, married, and has 3 children aged 1-13 years old. The children’s educational levels are kindergarten to 6th grade. 
Siah is illiterate due to poverty. She and her children live in the Telbomai Quarter, but work in the Central market of Voinjama city, the capital of Lofa county, northern Liberia . Her business is rice sales. She buys rice by bag and sells retail in the Voinjama central market, Voinjama city Lofa County, Liberia. Siah has been running this business for 3 years, and hopes to improve business to a store. She takes good care of her customers in order to encourage them to continue patronizing her business.
Siah needs this loan to purchase rice wholesale to improve business. She dreams of helping her children achieve their education.

loans.use: To purchase rice wholesale to improve business.

loans.name: Bella's Group

texts.en:
Bella B. is from the village of Namnama, Cabatuan, Isabela. She is 37 years-old. Bella is the leader of a five member group loan offered by Kiva partner ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Bella is married and has two school-aged children. Bella owns and operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Bella has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 500 daily.

In 2009, Bella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bella is requesting a first loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To provide additional capital.

loans.name: Fatou Ndiolé

texts.fr: Fatou Ndiolé N. est âgée de 54 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 4 ans. Elle achète des moutons, les engraisse pendant au moins trois mois et les revend. Cette activité lui procure des bénéfices qui lui permettent de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie familiales
texts.en:
Fatou Ndiolé N. is a 54 year-old married mother of two. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois for four years. She purchases sheep, fattens them, and then sells them on after three months. This enterprise generates profits that enable her to contribute actively to improving her family’s quality of life.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improving her livestock business

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en: K. Nguyễn Thị (20203020002) is a 50-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. K. is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by SEDA, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Đông Thái 1 - Nhóm 02 (Nhóm 02). K. is married and has three adult children. To make a living, K. works in and operates someone else's manufacturing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling clay products to local businesses and community members. K. has been engaged in this business for over three years and earns approximately 3.000.000 Vietnamese Dong a month from these activities. K. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. K. is requesting for the first time a loan from SEDA. She is requesting a loan of 5.152.000 VND, which will be used to purchase tools and other equipment to expand the business. K. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. Dương Thị P. (20203020003) is a 23-year-old female who is requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 2. Dương Thị H. (20203020005) is a 51-year-old female who is also requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 3. Trương Thị Thanh H. (20203020007) is a 24-year-old female who is also requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 4. Nguyễn Thị D. (20203020009) is a 48-year-old female who is also requesting a 5.152.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 5. Phùng Thị H. (20203020010) is a 33-year-old female who is also requesting a 4.256.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. About SEDA: The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. K. Nguyễn Thị (20203020002) là 50 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh. K. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Đông Thái 1 - Nhóm 02 (Nhóm 02). Trong khi không pH. chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh D. chủ yếu từ sản xuất & bán các sản phẩm bằng đất sét cho các D. nghiệp và người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương. K. thực hiện công việc kinh D. này trong hơn 3 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, K. kiếm được khoảng 3.000.000 VND. K. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh D. của cô ấy/ anh ấy. K. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây từ SEDA. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 1st khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Dương Thị P. (20203020003) là 23 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. Dương Thị H. (20203020005) là 51 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là chăn nuôi gia súc. 3. Trương Thị Thanh H. (20203020007) là 24 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. Nguyễn Thị D. (20203020009) là 48 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.152.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là chăn nuôi gia súc. 5. Phùng Thị H. (20203020010) là 33 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 4.256.000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh D. trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh D. là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về SEDA: Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các D. Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. .

loans.use: To purchase tools and other equipment to expand the business

loans.name: Mrs. Heng Chuong Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan group, which consists of 21 people, is located I. Trapeang Angk village I. Takeo province.  All the members will use their loans I. different ways. Mrs. Heng C., the village bank president, will use part of her loan to buy fertilizers for her rice field, and will use the rest to buy fuel for her irrigation machine which waters the rice field.  Her husband, Mr. S. Sam, helps her with the farming. Mrs. Heng C. is a 46-year-old mother with three children, one of whom is working I. a garment factory, while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is a 57 year old single mother of five. Two of her children attend school. She has been running a cafe for two years where she sells food and beverages. She has two employees to assist her in the business.  She also sells cereals to increase her earnings. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has learned how to save her money. She hopes to open a restaurant and build a house for her family in the future.  She has requested a loan of kes 60,000 to renovate her business premises. She describes herself as hardworking and ambitious.

loans.use: To renovate the business premises

loans.name: Luke

texts.en:
Luke E. is currently in the business of selling bread and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to buy a stock of onions to sell.  Luke E. is 43 years old and is widowed. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy stock of onions to sell

loans.name: Jamileth Del Rosario

texts.es: Jamileth del Rosario es cliente de nuestra institución desde hace mucho tiempo por lo que tiene una amplia experiencia en financiamientos. Su actividad económica es el servicio de bar y comedor. Ya que este negocio inicio hace más de 15 años, por lo que ha sido de gran ayuda para ella. Por lo que siempre ha sido una mujer muy responsable con sus cuotas. Ella está solicitando este financiamiento para la compra de gaseosa, jugos, granos básicos, verduras y frutas. Ella sueña con seguir adelante con su negocio.
texts.en:
Jamileth del Rosario has been a client of our institution for a long time so she has extensive experience managing loans. She has had a restaurant/bar for over 15 years which has been of great utility for her. She has always been very responsible with her loan installment repayments. She is asking for funding to buy soft-drinks, juices, basic grains, fruits and vegetables. She dreams with being able to continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food and drinks.

loans.name: Avelina

texts.en:
Avelina L. is from the town of Poblacion, Quezon, Bukidnon Province. She is 58 years old. Avelina is married and has ten adult children. To make a living, Avelina owns and operates a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing general alteration and tailoring services to local community members. Avelina has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Avelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Avelina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabrics and materials. This loan will be Avelina's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics and materials

loans.name: Sochida

texts.ru: Имомова Сочида проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 34 года. Вдова, имеет 2 детей. Образование - среднее. Сочида, портниха. Она в основном шьет платье для продажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для покупки ткани и ниток.
texts.en:
Sochida I. lives in the Rudaki region. She is 34 years old. She is a widow and has two children. She has secondary education. Sochida is a seamstress. She mainly sews dresses for sale. She has been doing this for six years now. She is taking out the loan to buy fabrics and threads.

Translated from Russian by Elena Bortnikoff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabrics and threads

loans.name: Sopey Dabakh Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité SOPEY DABAKH  composé est de sept femmes âgées en moyenne de 30 ans et sont toutes mariées exceptée la présidente du groupe Fatou Ndao SALL, et issues du même Banc Villageois qui porte le même nom que celui du quartier DIAMAGUENE. Elles se sont par affinité et solidairement pour s’entre aider à mener leurs activités commerciales constituées généralement de vente de divers produits halieutiques tels des poissons séchés et/ou fumés des huitres et crevettes séchés, la vente de tissus et de produits cosmétiques.
   
Le groupe est l’un des huit qui forment l’assemblée générale dudit Banc Villageois implanté au cœur du quartier et qui compte à son actif 90 membres toutes des femmes. Le groupe a été créé en même temps que le Banc Villageois depuis 2 ans et demi. Madame Astou GUEYE, pour des raisons de maladie de ma maman n’est pas dans la photo, elle devrait l’accompagner pour des soins médicaux à l’hôpital. 

Quant à la présidente Fatou Ndao F., au milieu de la photo exhibant un large sourire et vêtue de boubou blanc parsemé de fleurettes bleues et de pagne bleu, est âgée de 23 ans. Elle est célibataire sans enfant. Grâce à son assiduité et son dynamisme elle a été élue responsable du groupe. Elle vend essentiellement des tissus et des produits cosmétiques. Et l’objet de son crédit est de renforcer son capital d’investissement et son objectif est de renforcer son niveau d’épargne et prendre en charge ses besoins personnels. 

En sus des activités de remboursements ponctuels du groupe, les femmes en manière générale participent à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de leurs familles respectives.
texts.en:
The SOPEY DABAKH solidarity group consists of seven women 30 years old on average, all married excepting the group’s president Fatou Ndao SALL, and all from the same “Banc Villageois” loan group carrying the same name as the DIAMAGUENE borough. They came together through personal affinity and the desire to help each other manage their business activities, mainly concerned with various seafood products such as dried or smoked fish, dried oysters and shrimp, or the sale of clothing fabric and beauty products. The group is one of eight that constitute the “Banc Villageois” loan group, rooted in the centre of the borough and numbering 90 members, all women. The group was created at the same time as the Banc Villageois, 2 ½ years ago. Mrs Aston GUEYE is not in the picture, as she had to take her ailing mother to the hospital for medical treatments. The president Fatou Ndao SALL (23 years old) is in the middle of the picture wearing a wide smile and a white “boubou” strewn with blue flowers and a blue pagne. She is unmarried without children. She was elected group responsible due to her assiduity and dynamism. She retails mainly clothing fabrics and beauty products. The purpose of her loan is to strengthen her working capital and her objective is to bolster her savings and take charge of her personal needs. In addition to reimbursing the group loan, the women contribute in general to the improvement of their respective families’ living conditions.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: reinforce the group's investment capabilities

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok C., 48, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. C. and her husband are farmers and earn an income of USD 1 each per day. C. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new motorbike for one of her children to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike

loans.name: Natalio

texts.es:
A la vivienda del señor Natalio S. le esta haciendo falta la barda al frente de sus casa, pero por el momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para empezara la construcción, ya que desea que su familia este segura cuando el no esta en casa.
Es por eso que esta solicitando un préstamo, ya planea pagarlo con el ingreso que obtienen como oficial de validad en la ciudad. 
La persona que aparece en la foto es la señora Nadia Berenice Pérez esposa del señor Natalio ya que el se encontraba en su trabajo el día de la visita.
texts.en:
Natalio S. is lacking a fence in the front of his house, but at this time he doesn't have enough money to start the construction. He wants his family to be safe when he is not at home. That is why he is asking for a loan, and he is planning on paying for it with the income he receives from his job as a traffic officer in the city. The person in the photo is Nadia Berenice Pérez, wife of Natalio, since he was at work the day of the visit.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a fence in front of his house.

loans.name: Melchora

texts.en:
Melchora C. is from the village of  Gingoog City. She is 46 years old. Melchora is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Melchora owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Melchora is just starting this business.

In 2010, Melchora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melchora is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Melchora from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food  products for sale

loans.name: Gan-Ulzii

texts.en:
Gan-Ulzii H. is 27 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hentiy province, eastern of Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Gan-Ulzii operates a wooden products trading business at the regional market in his province with the help of his wife. He has operated in this trade for the last 3 years and has become quite experienced. Gan-Ulzii is very skillful and his customers are very satisfied with his wooden products. His monthly production ranges from 3 to 4 wooden doors of ger and 1 to 2 wooden door of houses which earn constant sales revenues of approximately 500,000 MNT. 

His business is very important to his family life as a source of family income. Gan-Ulzii is a hardworking, optimistic, modest person who is keen on helping to others. He dislikes being an " idle hand" and always seeks to do something productive for his work and life. He says, “My children are still young, so I need to begin saving for their future education.” He is requesting a 500,000 MNT loan to purchase an old house in order to reuse its wood for his business.

loans.use: To purchase an old house

loans.name: Un Millon De Amigos Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Millón D. Amigos esta conformado por 11 socias que se dedican a diversas actividades como la venta cereales, ropa, comida, calzados.
Como es el caso D. Alejandra que es Fiscal D. su Banco Comunal y lo que mas le agrada es el incentivo al ahorro con lo cual tiene proyectado construir su casa, actualmente vive en la casa D. su hermana. Alejandra en los próximos días comprara un terreno para su casa. Alejandra es soltera, tiene 4 hijos D. los cuales solo 1 esta a su responsabilidad, Alejandra tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, carnes, verduras, negocio que inicio hace 6 meses y le esta yendo muy bien, además Alejandra venD. comida los días sábados y domingos en el mismo lugar.
Alejandra solicita un préstamo que será invertido como parte D. pago para la compra D. un terreno.
Los sueños D. Alejandra son construir su casa y que su hija sea profesional.
texts.en:
The Millón D. Amigos [A Million Friends] Community Bank has 11 members who have different jobs such as cereal sales, clothing sales, food sales, and shoe sales. Alejandra is a member of this community bank. She is most grateful for the incentive to save money, with which she plans to build her house. She currently lives in her sister's home. In the next few days Alejandra will buy land for her home. Alejandra is single and has 4 children, of whom only 1 is her responsibility. Alejandra has a store in her home where she sells general groceries: meat and vegetables. She started this business 6 months ago and it is going very well. Alejandra also sells food on Saturdays and Sundays. She is requesting a loan which will cover part of the payment for her land. Her dreams are to build her home, and that her daughter will be a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Christine Cooper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: for the purchase of land.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.en: Mercedes L.'s main source of income comes from raising pigs for breeding. She is 43 years old, married and has two grown-up children. She is from the village of Parog Parog, Solana, Cagayan. Mercedes has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2005, Mercedes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Mercedes has successfully repaid a previous loan of 29,000 PHP from ASKI. She is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase medication for her livestock. This will be her seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use additional revenue to make improvements to her house. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase medication for her livestock

loans.name: Knight

texts.en:
Knight V. is a married woman with two children who are seven and two years old. She hopes to provide them with a quality education to the university level. 

Her business is located at a very busy market known as Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is part of the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, including the white beaches of the Indian Ocean. She owns a general store in which she sells such items as kerosene, detergents, sugar, flour and others. She has been in this business for three years now and she has two employees. 

She says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge she has is that some of her customers are not paying their debts as per agreement, making it hard for her to maximize profits. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more general items to expand her business and to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. She describes herself as obedient and tolerant.

loans.use: To buy kerosene, sugar, maize flour, etc. to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Narciso

texts.en:
Narciso B. is from the village of Divisoria Santiago. He is 39 years old. Narciso is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Narciso owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling scrap metal and other used products in the local community. Narciso has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Narciso joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Narciso has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Narciso is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Narciso from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
